sen.j: 蘇我果安（そがのはたやす、生年不明 - 天武天皇元年（672年）7月2日?）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: SOGA no Hatayasu (year of birth unknown - August 3?, 672) was a person who lived in the Asuka period of Japanese history.
SOGA no Hatayasu (year of birth unknown - August 3?, 672) was a person who lived during Japan's Asuka period.
sen.cmt: 他ファイルのネイティブチェックを参考に修正しました。
sen.e: SOGA no Hatayasu (year of birth unknown - August 3?, 672) was a person who lived during Japan's Asuka period.

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みは同じ。
sen.e: His name is pronounced the same way in old Japanese syllabary characters.
His name is pronounced the same in the old Japanese kana syllabary.
sen.cmt: 他ファイルのネイティブチェックを参考に修正しました。
sen.e: His name is pronounced the same in the old Japanese kana syllabary.

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）は臣。
sen.e: His kabane (hereditary title) was Omi.
sen.cmt: 臣→括弧内に姓の説明があるので、臣についてはそのままローマ字表記のみとしました。
sen.e: His kabane (hereditary title) was Omi.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Omi.

sen.j: 671年に御史大夫となり、大友皇子（弘文天皇）および他の4人の重臣とともに、重篤の天智天皇の詔を奉じることを誓った。
sen.e: He became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) in 67１, and together with Prince Otomo (Emperor Kobun) and other four senior vassals, he swore to obey an imperial edict issued by Emperor Tenchi who was in serious condition.

He became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) in 67１, and together with Prince Otomo (Emperor Kobun) and other four senior vassals, he swore to obey an imperial edict issued by Emperor Tenchi who was in serious condition.
sen.cmt: ピリオド前のスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: He became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) in 67１, and together with Prince Otomo (Emperor Kobun) and other four senior vassals, he swore to obey an imperial edict issued by Emperor Tenchi who was in serious condition.

sen.j: 天智天皇の死後、672年の壬申の乱で大友皇子の将軍になったが、内訌を起こして自殺した。
sen.e: After the death of Emperor Tenchi, he became shogun on the side of Prince Otomo in the Jinshin War in 672, but committed suicide after having internal discord.
sen.cmt: 大友皇子の将軍→大友皇子”側”の将軍と訳しました。
sen.e: After the death of Emperor Tenchi, he became shogun on the side of Prince Otomo in the Jinshin War of 672, but committed suicide after having internal discord.
sen.cmt: 前置詞を修正しました。
sen.e: After the death of Emperor Tenchi, he became shogun on the side of Prince Otomo in the Jinshin War of 672, but committed suicide after having internal discord.

sen.j: 蘇我果安は蘇我倉麻呂の子で、蘇我馬子の孫にあたる。
sen.e: SOGA no Hatayasu was a child of SOGA no Kuramaro and a grandchild of SOGA no Umako.
SOGA no Hatayasu was a child of SOGA no Kuramaro and a grandchild of SOGA no Umako.
SOGA no Hatayasu was a child of SOGA no Kuramaro and a grandchild of SOGA no Umako.

sen.j: 倉麻呂の系統は645年に蘇我蝦夷と蘇我入鹿が滅んでから蘇我氏の本流になった。
sen.e: Kuramaro's family line became a main lineage of SOGA clan after SOGA no Emishi and SOGA no Iruka died in 645.
Kuramaro's family line became a main lineage of SOGA clan after SOGA no Emishi and SOGA no Iruka died in 645.
Kuramaro's family line became a main lineage of SOGA clan after SOGA no Emishi and SOGA no Iruka died in 645.

sen.j: 果安のほかに蘇我石川麻呂、蘇我日向、蘇我赤兄、蘇我連子が兄弟としている。
sen.e: SOGA no Ishikawamaro, SOGA no Himuka, SOGA no Akae and SOGA no Murajiko were the brothers of Hatayasu.
SOGA no Ishikawamaro, SOGA no Himuka, SOGA no Akae and SOGA no Murajiko were the brothers of Hatayasu.
SOGA no Ishikawamaro, SOGA no Himuka, SOGA no Akae and SOGA no Murajiko were the brothers of Hatayasu.

sen.j: 蘇我果安は、天智天皇10年（671年）1月5日に、巨勢人、紀大人とともに御史大夫になった。
sen.e: SOGA no Hatayasu became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) together with KOSE no Hito and KI no Ushi in February 22, 671.
SOGA no Hatayasu became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) together with KOSE no Hito and KI no Ushi in February 22, 671.
SOGA no Hatayasu became Gyoshi taifu (a chief of controlling the officials) together with KOSE no Hito and KI no Ushi in February 22, 671.

sen.j: 同日に大友皇子が太政大臣、蘇我赤兄が左大臣、中臣金が右大臣に任命されており、御史大夫はこれに次ぐ重職であった。
sen.e: On the same day, Prince Otomo, SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane were appointed Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), Sadaijin (Minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), respectively, and Gyoshi taifu was an important post next to them.

On the same day, Prince Otomo, SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane were appointed Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), Sadaijin (Minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), respectively, and Gyoshi taifu was an important post next to them.

On the same day, Prince Otomo, SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane were appointed Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister), Sadaijin (Minister of the left) and Udaijin (minister of the right), respectively, and Gyoshi taifu was an important post next to them.

sen.j: その年の10月17日、重病の天智天皇は大海人皇子（後の天武天皇）を大殿に呼び入れた。
sen.e: On November 26 of the same year, Emperor Tenchi who was critically ill called Prince Oama (later Emperor Tenmu) to Otono (a palace or residence of the nobility).
sen.cmt: 大殿：Otono (a palace or residence of the nobility) と括弧で説明を補足しました。
sen.e: On November 26 of the same year, Emperor Tenchi who was critically ill called Prince Oama (later Emperor Tenmu) to Otono (a palace or residence of the nobility).
On November 26 of the same year, Emperor Tenchi who was critically ill called Prince Oama (later Emperor Tenmu) to Otono (a palace or residence of the nobility).

sen.j: このとき大海人皇子は、皇后を次の天皇にたて、大友皇子を皇太子にするよう進言し、あわせて自らの出家を申し出た。
sen.e: At the time, Prince Oama advised Emperor Tenchi to designate the Empress as the next emperor and Prince Otomo as the crown prince, while telling that he would enter into priesthood.
At the time, Prince Oama advised Emperor Tenchi to designate the Empress as the next emperor and Prince Otomo as the crown prince, while telling that he would enter into priesthood.
At the time, Prince Oama advised Emperor Tenchi to designate the Empress as the next emperor and Prince Otomo as the crown prince, while telling that he would enter into priesthood.

sen.j: 天皇に疑われていることを悟り、謀反の疑いを解きつつ近江宮から離れたものと考えられる。
sen.e: It is thought that he left Omi no miya (Omi Court) clearing himself from the suspicion of a rebellion, as he knew he was suspected by the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 近江宮→Omi no miya (Omi Court) と括弧で説明を補足しました。
sen.e: It is thought that he left Omi no miya (Omi Court) clearing himself from the suspicion of a rebellion, as he knew he was suspected by the Emperor.
It is thought that he left Omi no miya (Omi Court) clearing himself from the suspicion of a rebellion, as he knew he was suspected by the Emperor.

sen.j: 2日後、僧の服を着て吉野に向かう大海人皇子を、果安は蘇我赤兄や中臣金とともに莬道（宇治市）まで見送った。
sen.e: Two days later, together with SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane, Hatayasu went to Todo (Uji City) to see off Prince Oama in a priest's robe who left for Yoshino.
Two days later, together with SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane, Hatayasu went to Todo (Uji City) to see off Prince Oama in a priest's robe who left for Yoshino.
sen.cmt: ピリオド前のスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Two days later, together with SOGA no Akae and NAKATOMI no Kane, Hatayasu went to Todo (Uji City) to see off Prince Oama in a priest's robe who left for Yoshino.

sen.j: 11月23日に、大友皇子を含めて上に挙げた六人の重臣は、内裏の西殿の織物仏の前で誓盟を交わした。
sen.e: On January 1, 672, the above mentioned six senior vassals including Prince Otomo swore an oath in front of Orimono botoke (織物仏) (Buddha statue) in Nishi dono(西殿) (west side of the palace) of Dairi (Imperial Palace).
sen.cmt: 11月23日→新暦だと翌年に変わるので、訳文に年号を入れました。織物仏→Orimono botoke (Buddha statue) (正しい読み方、定訳不明です)。西殿→Nishi dono (west side of the palace) (正しい読み方、定訳不明です)。
sen.e: On January 1, 672, the above mentioned six senior vassals including Prince Otomo swore an oath in front of a tapestry image of the Buddha in the west hall of the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: "The emergence of Japanese kingship" by Joan R. Piggottを参照しました（google books)。
sen.e: On January 1, 672, the above mentioned six senior vassals including Prince Otomo swore an oath in front of a tapestry image of the Buddha in the west hall of the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: まず大友皇子が手に香炉をとって立ち、下記のように誓った。
sen.e: Firstly, Prince Otomo stood up with koro (license burner) in his hand, and swore as follows:
sen.cmt: 「下記のように」を追加して、「」外の文章を別の行にしました。
sen.e: Firstly, Prince Otomo stood up with koro (incense burner) in his hand, and swore as follows:
Firstly, Prince Otomo stood up with koro (incense burner) in his hand, and swore as follows:

sen.j: 「六人心を同じくして天皇の詔を奉じる。」
sen.e: 'We, six of us, obey the imperial edict in the same spirit.'
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。
sen.e: 'We, six of us, obey the imperial edict in the same spirit.'
'We, six of us, obey the imperial edict in the same spirit.'

sen.j: 「もし違うことがあれば必ず天罰を被る。」
sen.e: 'If we fail to do so, we will receive divine punishment."
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。
sen.e: 'If we fail to do so, we will receive divine punishment."
'If we fail to do so, we will receive divine punishment."

sen.j: あとの五人も香炉を手にして次々に立ち、下記のように泣きながら言った。
sen.e: The other five vassals also stood up one after another and said in tears as follows:
sen.cmt: 「下記のように」を追加して、「」外の文章を別の行にしました。
sen.e: The other five vassals also stood up one after the other with the incense burner in hand and said in tears as follows:
sen.cmt: 「香炉を手に」の訳を補足しました。
sen.e: The other five vassals also stood up one after the other with the incense burner in hand and said in tears as follows:

sen.j: 「臣ら六人、殿下に従って天皇の詔を奉じる。」
sen.e: 'We, the six vassals, obey the imperial edict under his imperial highness.'
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。殿下に従って→意味解釈が困難ですが、”殿下のもとで”と訳しました。
sen.e: 'We, the six vassals, obey the imperial edict under his imperial highness.'
'We, the six vassals, obey the imperial edict under his imperial highness.'

sen.j: 「もし違うことがあれば四天王が打つ。」
sen.e: 'If we fail to do so, Shitenno (four guardian kings) will punish us.'
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。
sen.e: 'If we fail to do so, Shitenno (four guardian kings) will punish us.'
'If we fail to do so, Shitenno (four guardian kings) will punish us.'

sen.j: 「天神地祇も誅罰する。」
sen.e: 'The gods of heaven and earth will also punish us.'
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。
sen.e: 'The gods of heaven and earth will also punish us.'
'The gods of heaven and earth will also punish us.'

sen.j: 「三十三天はこのことを証し知れ。」
sen.e: 'Sanjusanten (a class of gods residing in the second of the six heavens into which the realm of desire is divided in Buddhist cosmology) will be a witness.'
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。三十三天→Sanjusanten (a class of gods residing in the second of the six heavens into which the realm of desire is divided in Buddhist cosmology) と訳しました。
sen.e: 'Sanjusanten (a class of gods residing in the second of the six heavens into which the realm of desire is divided in Buddhist cosmology) will be a witness.'
'Sanjusanten (a class of gods residing in the second of the six heavens into which the realm of desire is divided in Buddhist cosmology) will be a witness.'

sen.j: 「子孫が絶え、家門が滅びよう」
sen.e: 'We will fail to have descendants and our family line will fail."
sen.cmt: その後の文章について分割、一文となるように「」をつけました。
sen.e: 'We will fail to have descendants and our family line will fail."
'We will fail to have descendants and our family line will fail."

sen.j: 29日に五人の臣は大友皇子を奉じて天皇の前で誓った。
sen.e: On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of the Emperor.
On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of the Emperor.
On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of the Emperor.

sen.j: 以上の『日本書紀』の記述では「天皇の詔」の具体的内容が明らかにされないが、一般には大友皇子を次の天皇に擁立することと理解されている。
sen.e: Although the above description in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) does not clearly state the contents of the 'imperial edict', it is generally believed to make Prince Otomo the next emperor.

Although the above description in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) does not clearly state the contents of the 'imperial edict', it is generally believed that the edict was to make Prince Otomo the next emperor.

Although the above description in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) does not clearly state the contents of the 'imperial edict', it is generally believed that the edict was to make Prince Otomo the next emperor.

sen.j: 29日に五人の臣は大友皇子を奉じて天智天皇の前で盟した。
sen.e: On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of Emperor Tenchi.
On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of Emperor Tenchi.
On 7th, the five vassals under Prince Otomo swore in front of Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: 内容は不明だが、前の誓いと同じだと思われる。
sen.e: Although the contents of the oath was unknown, it is thought to be the same oath as before.
Although the contents of the oath was unknown, it is thought to be the same oath as before.
Although the contents of the oath was unknown, it is thought to be the same oath as before.

sen.j: 12月3日に天智天皇は死んだ。
sen.e: On January 10, Emperor Tenchi died.
On January 10, Emperor Tenchi died.
On January 10, Emperor Tenchi died.

sen.j: 大海人皇子は翌年の6月22日に反乱に踏みきり、美濃国の不破郡に兵を集めてそこに移った。
sen.e: On July 25, Prince Oama decided to raise a rebellion, and moved to Fuwa County, Mino Province, where he had gathered troops.
sen.cmt: 翌年の6月22日→新暦では既に672年なので、訳出しませんでした。
sen.e: On July 25, Prince Oama decided to raise a rebellion, and moved to Fuwa County, Mino Province, where he had gathered troops.
On July 25, Prince Oama decided to raise a rebellion, and moved to Fuwa County, Mino Province, where he had gathered troops.

sen.j: このとき、山部王、蘇我果安、巨勢比等（巨勢人）が、数万の兵力を率いて大海人皇子を討つべく不破に向けて進発した。
sen.e: At that time, Yamabe no Okimi, SOGA no Hatayasu and KOSE no Hito set off for Fuwa with tens of thousands of troops to attack Prince Oama.
sen.cmt: 巨勢比等（巨勢人）→漢字表の違いは文脈に関係しないので特に訳出しませんでした。
sen.e: At that time, Yamabe no Okimi, SOGA no Hatayasu and KOSE no Hito set off for Fuwa with tens of thousands of troops to attack Prince Oama.
At that time, Yamabe no Okimi, SOGA no Hatayasu and KOSE no Hito set off for Fuwa with tens of thousands of troops to attack Prince Oama.

sen.j: しかし7月2日頃、犬上川の岸に陣を敷いたとき、山部王は果安と比等に殺された。
sen.e: However, around August 3, when they pitched a camp on the bank of Inukami-gawa River, Yamabe no Okimi was killed by Hatayasu and Hito.
However, around August 3, when they pitched a camp on the bank of Inukami-gawa River, Yamabe no Okimi was killed by Hatayasu and Hito.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: However, around August 3, when they pitched a camp on the bank of Inukami-gawa River, Yamabe no Okimi was killed by Hatayasu and Hito.

sen.j: その理由は『日本書紀』に記されない。
sen.e: The reason is not stated in "Nihonshoki".
The reason is not stated in "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: The reason is not stated in "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 混乱のため進軍が滞った。
sen.e: The march was stopped due to confusion.
The march was stopped due to confusion.
The march was stopped due to confusion.

sen.j: 果安は帰ってから首を刺して自殺した。
sen.e: Hatayasu committed suicide by stabbing his neck after he returned.
Hatayasu committed suicide by stabbing his neck after he returned.
Hatayasu committed suicide by stabbing his neck after he returned.

sen.j: 壬申の乱が大海人皇子の勝利で終わってから、果安の子は配流された。
sen.e: After the Jinshin War was over with the victory of Prince Oama, Hatayasu's children were exiled.
After the Jinshin War was over with the victory of Prince Oama, Hatayasu's children were exiled.
After the Jinshin War was over with the victory of Prince Oama, Hatayasu's children were exiled.

sen.j: 結局内訌の性質はわからないが、少なくとも果安の側に大海人皇子に靡くような行動はなかったのであろう。
sen.e: Although the details of the internal discord are unknown, it is thought that Hatayasu at least had no intention to switch to the side of Prince Oama.
Although the details of the internal discord are unknown, it is thought that Hatayasu at least had no intention to switch to the side of Prince Oama.
Although the details of the internal discord are unknown, it is thought that Hatayasu at least had no intention to switch to the side of Prince Oama.
